neighborhoods.name: Old Town
neighborhoods.character: Medieval streets stacked along volcanic ridges with closes, wynds, and atmospheric courtyards.

location.description: UNESCO-listed historic core climbing from Holyrood Palace to Edinburgh Castle.

history.overview: Old Town grew within fortified walls from the 12th century, forming a vertical city of tenements and hidden closes.
history.significance: Heart of Scottish royal power, Reformation politics, and Enlightenment thinkers.
notable_events: Signing of the Treaty of Union debates (1706)
Founding of the University of Edinburgh's Old College

practical_info.safety: Busy and generally safe; cobblestones can be slippery in rain.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Early morning before tour groups or evenings during festival season.
practical_info.walkability: High but steep; expect many stairs and uneven paving.

attractions.name: Edinburgh Castle
attractions.description: Iconic castle with Crown Jewels, Stone of Destiny, and panoramic views.
attractions.appeal: Essential Scottish history with daily One o'Clock Gun.

attractions.name: Real Mary King's Close
attractions.description: Subterranean streets revealing life in 17th-century Edinburgh.

attractions.name: Scottish Parliament
attractions.description: Contemporary building with free tours explaining devolved government.
attractions.appeal: Architectural contrast at the foot of the Royal Mile.

activities.name: Ghost Walk
activities.description: Storytellers guide guests through haunted closes and vaults.

activities.name: Arthur's Seat Sunrise
activities.description: Ascend the extinct volcano for first light over the city.

stay_here_if: You want to step outside into history
You are attending festival shows all day
insider_tips: Use the closes connecting the Royal Mile to Cowgate for shortcuts.
Visit early on Sundays for unobstructed photos.

neighborhoods.name: New Town
neighborhoods.character: Elegant Georgian crescents, designer boutiques, and refined cocktail bars.

location.description: Planned 18th-century district north of Princes Street with grid layout and grand squares.

history.overview: Built during the Enlightenment to expand the city for wealthy residents fleeing crowded Old Town.
history.significance: Showcase of Georgian architecture and birthplace of the Scottish Enlightenment salons.

practical_info.safety: Very safe with late-night foot traffic and CCTV.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Evening for cocktails and illuminated monuments.
practical_info.walkability: Flat grid system with wide pavements.

attractions.name: Scott Monument
attractions.description: Climb 287 steps for city and castle views.

attractions.name: Scottish National Portrait Gallery
attractions.description: Portraits of influential Scots in a red sandstone neo-Gothic building.
attractions.appeal: Free entry and stunning Great Hall.

dining.name: Badger & Co.
dining.known_for: Wind in the Willows themed decor

activities.name: Princes Street Gardens Stroll
activities.description: Admire seasonal plantings under castle cliffs.

activities.name: George Street Cocktail Crawl
activities.description: Explore award-winning bars like Bramble and Panda & Sons.

stay_here_if: You enjoy luxury hotels and shopping
You want easy tram access to the airport
insider_tips: Many museums are free-plan rainy day visits.
Book rooftop bars for sunset views toward the castle.

neighborhoods.name: Stockbridge
neighborhoods.character: Leafy village vibe with Sunday markets, artisan shops, and riverside walks.

location.description: Northwest of New Town along the Water of Leith.

history.overview: Former mill town turned artists' enclave celebrating slow living and independent businesses.
history.significance: Victorian terraces and mews houses illustrate Edinburgh's 19th-century expansion.
notable_events: Opening of the Royal Botanic Garden at Inverleith

transit: Cycle paths along Water of Leith
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Sunday for the farmers' market and brunch.
practical_info.walkability: Flat, compact streets perfect for strolling.

attractions.name: Dean Village
attractions.description: Picturesque former milling village with cobbled lanes.

attractions.name: Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh
attractions.description: Expansive garden with Victorian glasshouses and Scottish plant collections.

activities.name: Water of Leith Walkway
activities.description: Scenic path linking Stockbridge with Leith and galleries.

activities.name: Stockbridge Market
activities.description: Sunday market selling artisan food, crafts, and produce.

stay_here_if: You want a neighborhood base with easy access to the center
You love independent cafes and boutiques
avoid_if: You prefer hotel amenities over apartments
insider_tips: Visit early to snap Dean Village before crowds.
Walk to Circus Lane for iconic Instagram shots.

neighborhoods.name: Leith
neighborhoods.character: Revitalised port with creative energy, Michelin dining, and waterfront bars.

location.description: Coastal district northeast of city centre around the Water of Leith docks.

history.overview: Once Scotland's busiest port, now a cultural hotspot blending maritime heritage with creative industries.
history.significance: Stage for historic trade with continental Europe and 21st-century regeneration success story.
notable_events: Arrival of the Royal Yacht Britannia (1998)

practical_info.safety: Generally safe; lively weekend nightlife on The Shore.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Evening for waterfront dining and sunsets.
practical_info.walkability: Flat promenades with long boardwalk stretches.

attractions.name: Royal Yacht Britannia
attractions.description: Tour the former floating palace of the Royal Family.
attractions.appeal: Insight into royal life with audio-guided decks.

attractions.name: Custom House
attractions.description: Georgian building hosting pop-up markets and art events.

dining.name: The Shore
dining.known_for: Classic fish dishes and live jazz

activities.name: Leith Theatre gig
activities.description: Historic theatre revived for festivals and concerts.

activities.name: Water of Leith cycle
activities.description: Cycle path to city centre and Pentlands.

stay_here_if: You want top-tier dining within walking distance
avoid_if: You need immediate access to Old Town sights
insider_tips: Take the tram from the airport straight to the Shore.
Sample small-batch spirits at Lind and Lime distillery.

neighborhoods.name: Southside & Meadows
neighborhoods.character: Student energy, green expanses, and cultural venues near the University of Edinburgh.

location.description: South of Old Town surrounding George Square and The Meadows park.

history.overview: Grew in the 18th century as planned terraces for academics and professionals.
history.significance: Academic heart of the city hosting festivals, lecture series, and innovative arts venues.
notable_events: Site of the International Science Festival

practical_info.safety: Safe but lively late at night with students.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Spring when cherry blossom lines the park.
practical_info.walkability: Excellent; flat pathways connect to Old Town.

attractions.name: Surgeons' Hall Museums
attractions.description: Medical curiosities and surgical history exhibits.

attractions.name: Summerhall
attractions.description: Arts hub with galleries, theatres, and Pickering's Gin distillery.

activities.name: Meadows Picnic
activities.description: Join locals for frisbee, picnics, and festivals on sunny days.

activities.name: Fringe Venues
activities.description: George Square Gardens hosts major Fringe stages each August.

stay_here_if: You enjoy green space and easy access to Old Town
You want festival venues on your doorstep
insider_tips: Rent a bike to explore the Innocent Railway path to Portobello.
Visit the Meadows farmers market on Saturdays May-September.

neighborhoods.name: Portobello
neighborhoods.character: Seaside suburb with Victorian promenade, independent shops, and cold-water swimming culture.

location.description: Three miles east of the city centre on the Firth of Forth coastline.

history.overview: 18th-century holiday resort that grew with seaside villas and grand baths.
history.significance: Edinburgh's beach escape with thriving independent community.

practical_info.safety: Relaxed and family-friendly; monitor tides when swimming.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Summer mornings for sea swims or winter for dramatic skies.
practical_info.walkability: Flat promenade ideal for cycling and prams.

attractions.name: Portobello Beach
attractions.description: Two-mile sandy stretch with views across the Firth of Forth.

attractions.name: Bellfield
attractions.description: Community-owned space hosting yoga, gigs, and markets.
attractions.appeal: Meet locals and support grassroots events.

activities.name: Sea Swim with Wild Ones
activities.description: Join local swimming club for sunrise dips.

activities.name: Promenade Cycle
activities.description: Hire a bike and ride the coastal path toward Musselburgh.

stay_here_if: You want a beach break near the city
You plan a longer stay with self-catering
insider_tips: Bring a towel year-round-locals swim in all seasons.
Visit Twelve Triangles for award-winning pastries after a beach walk.
